evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the baseline preliminary phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA baseline preliminary phase is supported by multiple independent observations, making alternative explanations less plausible.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA baseline preliminary data, indicating potential issues in crew interaction protocols.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the baseline preliminary phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The observed pushback incident and crew interactions are representative of communication/coordination breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if the incident was due to procedural deviation unrelated to communication.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents communication and coordination among crew and tug operators during pushback, showing a breakdown as the aircraft passed the TRP and hit a barrier, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the event was primarily a procedural deviation or a communication breakdown

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA baseline preliminary data, indicating potential issues in crew interaction protocols.

assumptions: The baseline preliminary data includes features related to crew communication and coordination failures
The described events reflect typical crew interaction protocols
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication protocols were followed without error
If environmental or marking deficiencies were the primary cause of the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew, but H4 indicates a failure to stop at the designated point, supporting a communication/coordination breakdown consistent with key features in the baseline data.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or environmental factors contributed more to the breakdown

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA baseline preliminary phase is supported by multiple independent observations, making alternative explanations less plausible.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination are critical to pushback safety
The observed sequence reflects coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or environmental causes
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the overrun
If environmental or marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple independent observations (H1-H4) show communication among crew and a sequence of actions indicating coordination issues leading to the aircraft overrunning the TRP, supporting the communication breakdown claim and making alternative explanations less plausible.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew interactions and possible unreported environmental factors
